identificationModule.briefTitle: Uric Acid, Klotho and Salt Sensitivity in Young Adults Born Preterm
identificationModule.officialTitle: Uric Acid, Klotho and Salt Sensitivity in Young Adults Born Preterm

collaborators.name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this research is to learn about how salt in the diet influences blood pressure in young adults who were born prematurely.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Premature birth is an emerging and important risk factor for hypertension and cardiovascular disease, as both preterm birth rates and infant survival increase worldwide. Hypertension and cardiovascular disease begin in early adulthood in individuals born prematurely, but the reasons especially in regard to the role of preterm birth are unknown. An improved understanding of why hypertension and cardiovascular disease occur in early adulthood in individuals born preterm will enable the development of prevention and treatment strategies to mitigate the burden of cardiovascular disease. Investigators propose to investigate these relationships mechanistically in a clinical trial of subjects born preterm to establish the SSBP (salt sensitivity of blood pressure) phenotype and study its relationship to CVD (cardiovascular disease) compared to a control group of healthy term- born peers. Investigators will then propose to determine if blocking UA (uric acid) formation improves SSBP and cardiovascular function in subjects born preterm.

armGroups.label: Preterm Group
armGroups.description: Subjects with very low birth weight (\<37 completed weeks' gestation and birth weight \<1500 g) will receive a dietary intervention (high/low salt diet) and FDA approved drug, Allopurinol

armGroups.label: Term-born control group
armGroups.description: Subjects with birth weight ≥2500 g will receive a dietary intervention (high/low salt diet)

interventions.name: Allopurinol
interventions.description: Study Part 2- Preterm group only: After Visit 5 preterm born participants will start allopurinol 200 mg daily PO for 6 weeks. The 1 week high and low salt diets and assessments will be repeated while on allopurinol.

interventions.name: Dietary Intervention
interventions.description: High-Na+ (250 mmol/d) and low-Na+ (50 mmol/d) standard isocaloric K+ diets (75 mmol/1000 kcal/d) for 1 week each as 3 meals and 1 snack a day provided by the Clinical Research Unit Metabolic Kitchen. Part 2 preterm only- the diets will be repeated while the participant is taking allopurinol.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Proportion with salt sensitivity of blood pressure at baseline via ABPM
primaryOutcomes.description: Defined as a ≥8 mmHg decrease in mean arterial blood pressure when moving from the high-Na+ to the low-Na+ phase, as measured on 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM).

primaryOutcomes.measure: Proportion with salt sensitivity of blood pressure after allopurinol via ABPM
primaryOutcomes.description: A ≥8 mmHg decrease in mean arterial blood pressure when moving from the high-Na+ to the low-Na+ phase while taking allopurinol, as measured on 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM).

The ratio between the change in 24-hour mean arterial pressure, as measured on 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring, and the change in 24-hour urine Na+ concentration when moving from the high-Na+ phase to the low-Na+ phase.

The ratio between the change in 24-hour mean arterial pressure, as measured on 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring, and the change in 24-hour urine Na+ concentration when moving from the high-Na+ phase to the low-Na+ phase while taking allopurinol

primaryOutcomes.measure: Proportion with salt sensitivity of blood pressure at baseline via casual blood pressure
primaryOutcomes.description: A \>=5 mmHg decrease in mean arterial blood pressure measured in clinic when moving from the high-Na+ phase to the low-Na+ phase. Casual blood pressure measured 3 consecutive times via auscultation with the average of the 3 mean arterial blood pressure measurements recorded.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Proportion with salt sensitivity of blood pressure after allopurinol via casual blood pressure
primaryOutcomes.description: A \>=5 mmHg decrease in mean arterial blood pressure measured in clinic when moving from the high-Na+ phase to the low-Na+ phase while taking allopurinol. Casual blood pressure measured 3 consecutive times via auscultation with the average of the 3 mean arterial blood pressure measurements recorded.

primaryOutcomes.measure: High blood pressure at baseline via ABPM
primaryOutcomes.description: Proportion with 24-hour mean systolic or diastolic blood pressure ≥115/75 mmHg, awake mean systolic or diastolic blood pressure ≥120/80 mmHg, or asleep mean systolic or diastolic blood pressure ≥100/65 mmHg, measured with ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM).

Proportion with 24-hour mean systolic or diastolic blood pressure ≥125/75 mmHg, awake mean systolic or diastolic blood pressure ≥130/80 mmHg, or asleep mean systolic or diastolic blood pressure ≥110/65 mmHg, measured with ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM).

primaryOutcomes.measure: High blood pressure at baseline via casual blood pressure
primaryOutcomes.description: Proportion with mean systolic or diastolic blood pressure ≥120/80 mmHg, measured via 3 consecutive auscultated measurements (averaged) at each of 3 separate study visits.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Hypertension at baseline via casual blood pressure
primaryOutcomes.description: Proportion with mean systolic or diastolic blood pressure ≥130/80 mmHg, measured via 3 consecutive auscultated measurements (averaged) at each of 3 separate study visits
Serum uric acid concentration at baseline

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in serum uric acid with dietary Na+ intervention
primaryOutcomes.description: The change in serum uric acid levels when moving from high-Na+ phase to the low-Na+ phase

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in serum uric acid with dietary Na+ intervention on allopurinol
primaryOutcomes.description: The change in serum uric acid levels when moving from high-Na+ phase to the low-Na+ phase while on allopurinol
Carotid femoral pulse wave velocity will be measured at baseline with the SphygmoCor XCEL device
Augmentation index will be measured at baseline with the SphygmoCor XCEL device
Heart rate variability will be measured at baseline using continuous heart rate recording using the CNAP™ Monitor 500i
Baroreflex sensitivity will be measured at baseline using continuous blood pressure and heart rate using the CNAP™ Monitor 500i
Plasma angiotensin-(1-7) concentration and urine angiotensin-(1-7)/creatinine at baseline
Plasma angiotensin II concentration and urine angiotensin II/creatinine at baseline
Plasma klotho concentration and urine klotho/creatinine at baseline.
Serum creatinine concentration at baseline
Serum cystatin C concentration at baseline
Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) at baseline.We will calculate the eGFR by the CKD-EPI Creatinine-Cystatin C 2012 equation and by 24 hour creatinine

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Born 1990-1998
* Singleton birth
* Born at less than 34 weeks gestational age (preterm cohort)
* Born at greater than 36 weeks gestational age (term cohort)

Exclusion Criteria:

* Twin birth
* Congenital anomalies or genetic syndromes
* Currently pregnant or breast feeding
* Subject-reported history of hypertension
* Current use of antihypertensive medications
* Active cancer
* Chronic kidney disease
* Heart failure
* Liver failure

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: IPD that underlie the results reported in this record, after deidentification.
ipdSharingStatementModule.timeFrame: Beginning 3 months and ending 5 years following publication.
ipdSharingStatementModule.accessCriteria: Proposals should be directed to hshaltou@wakehealth.edu. To gain access, data requestors will need to sign a data access agreement. Data are available for 5 years.
